items.title: Why American Giant Re-Designed Its Web Site
items.abstract: The metrics indicate the company made the right call. (Plus, the company has sold out all of its product.)

items.title: FedEx to Pay City $2.4 Million in Cigarette-Tax Settlement
items.abstract: From 2006 to 2009, the city said, FedEx Ground delivered about 160,000 cartons of untaxed cigarettes that New Yorkers had ordered from CigarettesDirect2U.com.

items.title: A Plan of Attack for the Urban Antique Hunter
items.abstract: Steven Sclaroff, a designer who has decorated Jack Spade stores, on finding treasure among “stuff you can’t believe has a price tag.”

items.title: In China's Urbanization, Worries of a Housing Shortage
items.abstract: The clearance of so-called villages within cities removes cheap housing stock for the very people chosen to fuel migration, without providing sufficient replacement units.

items.title: Where Urban Meets Suburban
items.abstract: Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is a neighborhood of unexpected juxtapositions.

items.title: New York City
items.abstract: New books include Gerard Koeppel’s “City on a Grid: How New York Became New York.”
keywords: City on a Grid: How New York Became New York (Book)
Fun City: John Lindsay, Joe Namath, and How Sports Saved New York in the 1960s (Book)
The Con Men: Hustling in New York City (Book)

items.title: Republicans Ignore a Poisoned City
items.abstract: Republicans talk about their commitment to the poor. So why haven’t we heard the party’s candidates talk about the crisis in Flint, Mich.?

items.title: The Battles of Wilmington, N.C. — in World War II, That Is
items.abstract: A historic trail proposed for North Carolina would amplify the coastal city’s role in World War II.

items.title: Your Monday Briefing: Ted Cruz, Aleppo, Leicester City
items.abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

items.title: In Amsterdam, Interior Design Gets a Centennial Splash
items.abstract: An exhibition at the Stedelijk Museum focuses on a little-known aspect of the Amsterdam School of design.

items.title: The Man Who Designed Dean & Deluca, and the Look of Modern Kitchens
items.abstract: In the ’70s, the artist Jack Ceglic created the gourmet grocer's aesthetic, with industrial touches aplenty. His own home in East Hampton is even more appealing.

items.title: New York Will Add 4 Statues of Women to Help Fix ‘Glaring’ Gender Gap in Public Art
items.abstract: The city plans to install four statues in four boroughs, which each of the historical figures once called home.

items.title: The Fight to Tame a Swelling River With Dams That May Be Outmatched by Climate Change
items.abstract: Along the Missouri, John Remus controls a network of dams that dictates the fate of millions. ‘It was not designed to handle this.’

items.title: Why Soft Power Is in Style in Qatar
items.abstract: Hundreds of influential faces in global politics, art, fashion and design descended on this tiny desert kingdom last week.

items.title: Hotel Review: The WineBox Valparaíso, Chile
items.abstract: A hotel — and urban winery — created out of shipping containers and wrapped in a blanket of sustainability makes its mark on the undulating hills of “Valpo.”

items.title: A Design Duo Adding Whimsy to Traditional Woodwork
items.abstract: The East London furniture makers Wilkinson & Rivera are giving classic silhouettes a playful twist.

items.title: The Next Affordable City Is Already Too Expensive
items.abstract: In Spokane, Wash., home prices jumped 60 percent in the past two years. The increase is fueled by buyers fleeing the boom in cities like Austin. Who will have to flee next?

items.title: Russia Advances on 3 Ukrainian Cities, but Meets Fierce Resistance
items.abstract: Ukraine’s leader said his forces had “repelled” the Russian army’s assault. Moscow claimed it had merely “paused” for the possibility of peace negotiations.

items.title: First Ukraine City Falls as Russia Strikes More Civilian Targets
items.abstract: Russian forces seized the southern city of Kherson and besieged other cities, with casualties and destruction mounting, as Western sanctions tightened their vise grip on Russia’s economy.

items.title: One week into the war and with cities under siege, a humanitarian crisis looms.
items.abstract: One day after Russian forces seized the first major city in their onslaught in Ukraine — potentially clearing the way for a bid to seize the entire Black Sea coast and cut off the country from world shipping — Russian forces on Thursday continued to lay siege to major cities, creating a dire humanitarian crisis.
